comment.body:
Both Antilibrary and the forum for such are listed under [Kaffiene's untagged index](http://127.0.0.1:43110/kaffiene.bit/?q=antilibrary&i=Kaffiene - Untagged). Unfortunately a lot of sites are like this at the moment, mostly due to my own incompetence. I need to fix up automatically grabbing descriptions/tags, or simply tag them by hand.

As for other search engines... I know most are dead and don't update their index anymore.
@Arsene Lupin: Right, there's lots of ways to do it. Zirch, as mentioned, just grabs some text. I don't have an auto-tagger finished yet for Kaffiene. It's been on the to-do.

It doesn't lie. Most of the free software developed today is licensed under the GPL, which restricts particular commercial uses. You cannot, for instance, take GPL licensed code, use it in a commercial product, and then ship that product and sell it. The BSD license, however, *does* allow you to do that. Which is why, IMO, it's superior.
RIP. ZeroVoat is so close yet so far from being a usable reddit clone.

@ZAlex: The 'freedoms' outlined on the page conflict with the GPL. You can't simultaneously say it's okay to keep modifications private and then require open sourcing it. Those two conflict.

To me, it looks like this was written before the GPL, and then was edited to try and make the GPL sound okay.

Ultimately, I'd rather not deal with the fuss. The 2 clause BSD license works fine. Giving to public domain works fine.

Edit: Also worth noting, you can't really make paid software free. Since the concept of purchasing software goes against the idea of redistributing it however you'd like.

@ZAlex: 

>my college lies about free software. Authors of the book state that "the majority of developers of free programs prohibit to use their software for commercial production."

-

>If the use of software requires a fee - this is not free software.

-

>These freedoms are applicable to both permissive and copyleft licenses.

These are three contradictory statements. You cannot say that your textbook lied, while saying copyleft is free software. The majority of free software is licensed under GPL, which restricts the sale of the software. As you mentioned. And thus, the majority of developers of free software prohibit use of their software in commercial production. It's straight forward.
@ZAlex: I'm well aware of what the GPL says. You cannot sell software unless you also provide the source. Thus, it prohibits the use of the software for commercial production.
@Krixano: You can take red hat and undercut the cost or distribute it free? I'm confused at how that's a workable business model.
Sorry, BSD is still more free.
@ZAlex: Eh. Just seems over restrictive and pushing reliance on the copyright system, which is exactly the opposite of what I'm after.
@ZAlex: Public domain is best, tbh. Which is what I release everything as. The 2-clause BSD license sounds fine though.
@ZAlex: It still restricts both usage and sale.
@ZAlex: And therefore you cannot sell the software if you do not release the source. That's restricting both usage and sale.

It's almost certainly the case that you're looking at the *same* account (1NWh...), except viewing the profile on two different hubs (red hub vs KaffieHub). This is because I migrated my profile a long time ago. However, follows are done not by hub but by auth_address.

Just 'follow' the proper one on KaffieHub, that'll help fix the links to my account. Thanks :)
Sounds like a fun talk. Please do upload/link it once the recording is available.
Nope. All file manipulation and logins are done by Zeronet itself, not the sites.
I'd love to go, but no money nor ability to actually get to the meetup location. Hope everyone has a good time though :)

@weakish: I don't have a passport or things like that. Probably don't have whatever medical things are required. As I mentioned no money, I still need local transportation to get to an airport, etc. It's not very practical for me, even if I did have flights/hotel/whatever covered.
Small file, fast peers.
there should be a warning that it's still downloading stuff.

It's great. Almost ready to use full time. IPV6+DHT+running over a meshnet is critically needed. Can't keep the web open/free/uncensored if you have to rely on trackers, IANA, and ISPs.

Really glad to see ZeroNet make it this far though :D
That's a shame. Why not just do something like KopyKate Big or ZeroUp? Would probably be easier than messing around with IPFS.
@Krixano: Ah, must've missed it on my first readthru.

>What would you like to see in 2018? :)

Finish up whatever's needed to run ZeroNet over cjdns. I think it's just setting up ipv6 at this point? I think I read that ipv6 support would help chinese users as well.

Just thought of another thing: an option to allow user certs from any provider, and just use a blacklist rather than a whitelist. There's already an option in the javascript for it, so there only needs to be a fix on the content.json/permissions side of things. Would help encourage more providers and help decentralize things a bit more.

@Nofish: I feel like that should be the choice of the developer. Have the option nonetheless. Perhaps people *don't care* which provider the cert is from? If there's an issue with some, have a blacklist. I'm requesting this feature because I'd like to use it on my sites, and to help promote it's use so that ID providers aren't monopolized and centralized. Having to add each new provider means that a site will eventually become useless. For example, look at sites that *require* a zeroverse ID. They're unusable.

I'm not a fan of the 'proof of work' thing. It's a waste of CPU cycles, and introduces a delay for people joining a service. I'd rather *not* have to buy a $200 GPU and then run it for 3 days before I can use zeronet properly. Why introduce fees and cost requirements to use the service? Really makes me wonder about the future of ZN: high connectivity with clunky blockchains, huge wasteful CPU requirements, high dollar barriers to entry, restrictive websites. I'm not a fan of these ideas. ZeroNet is great because it's decentralized and lightweight. Can basically be ran on a toaster at the moment.
@Jro: I'd be up for a regex-matching provider and auth_address permissions.

@Nofish: Sure. No need to depend on namecoin. As it stands, KaffieID isn't on kaffie.bit. It's on id.kaffie.bit. So when you click to 'register' it redirects to kaffie.bit. Personally, I just think the custom names would be fine. Imagine having a bunch of ids. All just: "1ZeroID[randomstuff]". You'd have no idea which is which.

But yeah, if the PoW is for the provider, then that's fine.
ZeroNet is now able to work on local networks.
wopergenderneutralchild. Fixed for you. "Son" is sexist. Or perhaps just "woperchild"
Windows is a virus.
@Daniell Mesquita: I don't? Lol. I use mac.

\>leaks sex tapes
\>claims to be a victim
Gawker is so full of shit.

Most people join after they hear about it, test it out, and then stop coming due to lack of activity. We have regular users who drop by every now and again, but may take long breaks. There's just not much going on here, so it's hard to stay active.

\>Trump

\>Best Speech

Yeah I'm not really sure those two things go together.
@Quantumworld: The video is censored. Do you have an uncensored copy?
@Quantumworld: I'm a far-left anarchist with some conservative social views.

@Quantumworld: lol. I have some odd views on the whole pregnancy/abortion issue. I support abortions up until the fetal stage of development. And after for medical emergencies (mother's life at risk). But I also support financial aid for parents, more streamlined adoption (and giving adoption rights to anyone who wants them), along with tech development like incubation and early births. A bit unrelated but I also support financial abortions for fathers. If the father wants to abort at a valid time, but the mother doesn't, then let the father sever his financial and legal connection to the kid and mother.

As for debates... I find a lot of people think they "win" after making a snarky remark without ever really addressing the topic properly. It's rare to see for either side.

@Quantumworld: I'm actually a bit torn on early abortions. Ideally they'd be banned. But realistically things work better if they aren't.

@leftside: The video is still edited though, yeah?
@Quantumworld: I'd still allow for abortions when there are medical complications. But yeah other than that ideally they shouldn't happen.
@Eightyfour: Rape is an example of why I support *early* pre-fetal abortions. Ideally it shouldn't happen, but it does. Rape is no excuse for a fetal/late abortion.
@Goodone: Hello chinese government, it's nice to see that you finally realized you can't censor us.

@梦里乾坤大: Coinhive is a bitcoin miner that runs in javascript. It can't run if you don't visit the page. It's not a virus. Just scare tactics. There *were* a few sites/pages that had the miner, but they're well known and there are blocklists and such for it now. Not widespread, and not a huge issue.
@Somename666: https://0net.io/0wiki.bit/?Page:home is a bit more elegant and still links there.

@Klu9: There's also kiwipedia, which has features to mirror actual wikipedia content with a click of a button.

We just need a remake of a wiki platform that can use hubs properly (not kiwipedia's "hub per language")

@Klu9: Absolutely agreed. Though on the hubs thing, "hub" refers to the data sites for a particular merger site. For example ZeroMe hubs, or 0gallery hubs, or Millchan hubs. Personally I like ZeroWiki's UX a lot better. But kiwipedia has that beautiful feature to auto-import wikipedia articles. Though there's a lot wrong with it (putting all of the articles in the same hub, and separating by language).

I'm pretty sure it's not actively developed either, unfortunately. We really do need a good wiki solution.

@Quantumworld: Yeah documentation is very limited for ZeroNet. There's only one kiwipedia, but two ZeroWikis. The ZeroWikis are different, as they aren't merger sites (meaning their content isn't shared).

@Klu9: There's very little documentation. Mostly just a couple of api function mentions in the docs, and that's about it. I've been meaning to write up a small example/tutorial merger site, so that people can easily clone it and adapt it to their own use. We probably also need a basic ZeroNet tutorial/how-to/information, which I also wanted to write haha. Lots to do.

@Quantumworld: The big problem with the technical documentation is that it's not exactly clear how to use each function in combination with one another. And nofish just writes in coffeescript which is basically confusing af to try and convert to some basic/simple javascript. Maybe I'm just an idiot though lol. Def not a fan of coffeescript.
You cannot dictate what others can view. If you don't want people seeing what you post, then don't post it.

@Quantumworld: blocking/muting makes it so you can't see their content. It doesn't stop people from posting or viewing content. So yes, it's not like twitter or facebook in that it doesn't have censorship.
Remember 15 years ago when nintendo did this?
@Somename666: I've met people who have believed all of these, yes. Absolute lunacy.
As with all ZN updates, it'll get here when it gets here.
Does it look like I give a shit about the law? I ain't going to censor my sites simply because authority wants me to. That's kinda the exact opposite of the goal here.
@leftside: The best designed zeronet sites don't have a single owner. How will they take down and censor something like ZeroMe? Users could just create new hubs.

@leftside: Right so an improved solution is to use merger sites properly, with all users posting to all hubs, rather than having "home hubs". That way if one is taken down, it's not a huge deal. Similar to how if one torrenting site is taken down, it's not a huge deal.

Regardless, you *can* have multiple signers for a site. Though I'm not sure it's been done before.
Do I need to switch to the python3 version? I tried updated and it doesn't work. I checked zeroupdate.bit and it says I'm on the latest version.
@Moor: Yeah just setup the python3 version and it works. Seems I missed quite a few updates? I'll have to read through the changelog.
If we could get an updated idname plugin that'd be awesome: https://github.com/geekless/ZeroNet/tree/IDName/plugins/IDName
